typeLines.text:
Long ago—
Two-legged thinkers walked the earth, called "humans."

They had food, roofs, and companions;
Abundance at the chest softened into a warm beam called "happiness."

When a sincere smile rippled from the heart,
we—the seeds of the Key-Heart—took root in silence.

We drank their joy and grew;
The brighter the heart, the faster we rose.

Yet the wind of the age
blew feelings to a "pale" hue.

"Pale"—the plainness of days,
and the sweetness on our tongues turning "faint."

Study, work, life—
In their mouths these outweighed "happiness."

Layer upon layer of weight
at last kindled the inescapable blaze.

Upon the ash that followed,
survivors vowed to rebuild a home for joy.

And we sprites, diving into the heart-sea,
went searching for the long-buried key.

Now you—newborn sprites—
will go to unlock more of humankind’s
H E A R T ’ S   L O C K S

Ethan’s Wind · Shell—
At nine, reliability rests upon his brow.

Morning grass slopes and wooden bridges—
where his stride and courage are trained.

He hauls wood, feeds sheep, mends windmills—
packing every “must-do” into his pocket.

Wind comes from the valley
and turns his small heartbeat into drums.

Outwardly—steady, dutiful, always running ahead;
Yet the true destination lies deeper in the wind.

Ethan’s Wind · Mind—
Wind brushes the ear; thoughts begin to web.

“Be a bit more reliable,”
he whispers to himself, adding one more weight.

School, chores, promises hang like rows of chimes—
Each ring is an echo of responsibility.

But when he recalls his mother’s silence,
the wind skips half a beat.

He tells himself:
“Care for everyone first—then wait for her to speak.”

That thought—folded neatly by the wind—
is tucked against his chest.

Ethan’s Wind · Soul—
Ridges steeper; cloud-shadows nearer.

An unremembered accident, like a veiled mountain path—
Only pebbles press lightly at the sole.

He chases a beam no one sees—
and is chased by a wind of misunderstanding.

“Don’t let the wind answer for me.”
Teeth set, he leaps from a broken bridge to the next cloud.

One step more—
and the outline of the heart-door will show upon the wind.

Ethan’s Wind · Self—
Where the wind calms, a lamp lights the greenhouse.

Wooden top, paper plane, the corner of a portrait—
Each returns to where it belongs.

“Mom will get better,” he says—
like easing a key into the lock.

When the embrace arrives, color flows back;
The wind no longer howls—only sings upon the eaves.

And he understands:
Reliability isn’t bearing all things—it's learning to walk with the wind.
